author: bridge-bot
content:
<mattsse> re: **@savidtech**
> we have a PR to geth extending ethstats client (https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/33395) to emit a new timing event around engine_newPayload.

the end goal is for ethpandaops to run a ethstats server to collect block times from contributoors (opt in) and anyone else who wants to send us el timing data. 

i haven't looked into other client implementations yet, feed back from other client teams much appreciated
this makes sense
tracking for reth here https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/20578

author: bridge-bot
content:
<sam_cm> re: **@shekhirin**
> I see that we have two Reth nodes rn, are they running different versions? I would assume one running release, and the other nightly? Results differ a lot üòÖ

https://lab.ethpandaops.io/ethereum/slots/13300064?tab=execution
Yeah they would've been due to different `docker pull` times - sorry. I've pinned both of them to the latest nightly release for now (https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pkgs/container/reth/620615936?tag=nightly). We can automate the deployment of `nightly` images next year if it'd be useful

author: bridge-bot
content: <gakonst> BTW slowest outlier blocks seem to basically always be XEN / some N-leg symbolic arb with hundreds of state accesses OR modexp relating to Aztec/ZKSync/ZkPass txs - so we seem in a good spot across the board

author: bridge-bot
content:
<marcin_d_s> According to current benchmarks (https://grafana.observability.ethpandaops.io/d/feo4ronhsqv40d/opcodes-benchmarking) with fixed number of instructions (and without precompiles), these are operations performing below 100MGas/s. 

I excluded cases where Besu was the only underperforming client, it was just too often and we likely need to improve the process.

Keccak in underperforming in all clients so I propose 2x repricing, in all other cases there is at least one client performing above 100MGas/s, so it is theoretically possible to improve without repricing.

Just FYI, there is already an EIP for tripling price of Point Evaluation precompile (https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/10864) and likely we will need to reprice also EcRecover, but we need to wait for accurate benchmark data for that.

Keccak in underperforming in all clients so I propose 2x repricing, in all other cases there is at least one client performing above 100MGas/s, so it is theoretically possible to improve without repricing.

author: bridge-bot

author: bridge-bot
content:
<louistsai> re: **@marcin_d_s**
> @gakonst it is this test case

@louistsai will know more about the structure of this case
The test name might be a bit confusing now. Its structure is:

`<folder_name>_<test_name>[test_ids]`

More on the structure of `test_name`, it is `test_<opcode>_<modifier>` for most of the cases.
We are adding a target opcode label for most of the benchmark tests for clarity now.
